Award.AwardTitle: Families of L-functions and automorphic forms
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI plans to investigate a variety of problems in the
analytic theory of automorphic forms, especially problems
concerning higher rank groups such as the general linear
group of degree 3 and higher. In particular, the PI will
study some problems concerning the analytic study of
automorphic forms restricted to small subsets, especially
period integrals. Other components of the research include
the study of mean values of L-functions including the Riemann
zeta function.

One of the goals of analytic number theory is to understand
the statistical properties of algebraic objects. For instance,
one can ask what is the probability that a randomly chosen
large number is a prime. It is very fortunate for modern
cryptography that it is easy to find large primes. Cryptography
is a crucial tool in banking, commerce, and of course national
security. Some of our best knowledge on the prime numbers
comes from properties of the Riemann zeta function, the
simplest L-function. Many other fascinating algebraic
and geometric objects are encoded in other types of L-functions.
The PI plans to study many of the statistical properties of
these L-functions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit
This project was focused on statistical properties of L-functions, automorphic forms, and the connections between these two different types of objects.  Automorphic forms and L-functions encode interesting information about the whole numbers 1,2,3, etc.  For instance, the simplest L-function, the Riemann zeta function, helps mathematicians to understand how the prime numbers are scattered amongst all the positive numbers.  Prime numbers are important for modern cryptography which uses them  to encrypt and decrypt messages (such as credit card numbers) for secure transmissions over the internet. 

L-functions are a unifying force in mathematics, as they appear in many otherwise disparate areas.  For instance, they occur in algebraic number theory, quantum chaos, mathematical physics, geometry, as well as classical analytic number theory (their original point of origin).  Techniques developed to study one of these problems can then be applied to others.  Much of the research undertaken by the PI has been to discover new settings where the theory of L-functions may be successfully applied.



Broader Impacts
The PI was involved in a summer REU program in 2013 and 2014 at Texas A&M University, which involved mentoring undergraduate students in number theory.  This program allowed undergraduates to participate in research in a meaningful way.  A large proportion of these REU students are members of underrepresented groups in mathematics, and/or come from universities with limited research opportunities.  The REU projects are intertwined with the PI's research program.

The PI also gave a cryptography mini-course to middle school students at a summer enrichment program at Texas A&M in 2012.  The PI furthermore twice ran an activity at the Texas A&M math circle in Spring 2013.  Mathematical Circles are a form of education enrichment and outreach that bring students into direct contact with mathematical professionals in an informal setting, to work on interesting problems or topics in mathematics. The goal is to get the students excited about the mathematics, giving them a setting that encourages them to become passionate about mathematics.

The PI also partcipated at the Bryan Collegiate High School career day in May 2014.  Early college schools, such as Bryan Collegiate, are designed so that low-income youth, first-generation college students, English language learners, students of color, and other young people underrepresented in higher education can simultaneously earn a high school diploma and one to two years of transferable college credit tuition free.  The career day was an opportunity to connect high school students to some of the exciting aspects of college mathematics, such as cryptography.
